topic.title: HP Helion OpenStack 2.0: Applying Input Model Changes to Existing Rings

body.p: This section describes a general approach of making changes to the existing rings. This applies to actions such as adding and removing a server and replacing and upgrading the disk drive(s). There are a number of phases that must be performed when adding and removing a server and replacing and upgrading the disk drive(s), as shown below:

li.p:
Do the following:
If not already done, set the weight-step attribute. (See Setting the weight-step attribute).
Edit the Input Model as appropriate. You must edit the YAML file as per your requirement. For more information, refer
Commit your configuration to the local repo, as follows:git add -A git commit -m "commit message"
Run the configuration processor:cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost config-processor-run.yml
Run the following command to create a deployment directory.cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost ready-deployment.yml
Run the following playbook.cd ~/helion/hos/ansible/ ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost _swift-validate-input-model.yml
Validate that the number of drives proposed to be added or deleted or weight change is correct. Fix any errors in your input model. At this stage, no changes have been made to rings.

Do the following:
Apply the input model changes to the rings, rebalance the rings and deploy them to all Swift nodes by running the following playbook:cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts swift-deploy.yml
Wait until replication has finished or min-part-time has elapsed (which ever is longer). For more information see

li.b: Weight change phase of ring rebalance:
li.p: At this stage, no changes are being made to the input model. However, when you set the weight-step attribute, the rings that was rebuilt in the previous rebalance phase have weights that are different than their target/final value. You gradually move to the target/final weight by rebalancing a number of times as described in this page. For more information about the weight-step attribute see Swift preparing ring changes.

Do the following:
Rebalance the rings by running the following playbook:cd ~/helion/hos/ansible/ ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost _swift-make-delta-rebalance.yml
Run the reconfigure.cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts swift-reconfigure.yml
Wait until replication has finished or min-part-time has elapsed (which ever is longer). For more information see
Run the following command cd ~/helion/hos/ansible/ ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost _swift-validate-input-model.ymland examine the report.
An example of the output after executing the above command. In the example no weight changes are proposed.TASK: [swiftlm-ring-supervisor | validate-input-model | Print report] ********* ok: [padawan-ccp-c1-m1-mgmt] => { "var": { "report.stdout_lines": [ "Need to add 0 devices", "Need to remove 0 devices", "Need to set weight on 0 devices" ] } }
When there are no proposed weight changes, you proceed the final phase.
If there are proposed weight changes repeat this phase again.

The final rebalance phase moves all replicas to their final destination.
Rebalance the rings by running the following playbook. cd ~/helion/hos/ansible/ ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost _swift-make-delta-rebalance.yml | tee /tmp/rebalance.logThe output is saved for later examination.
Examine the output from the previous step. If the output for all ring is similar to the following, the rebalance had no effect. That is, the rings are balanced and no further changes are needed. In addition, the ring files were not changed so you do not need to deploy them to the Swift nodes."Running: swift-ring-builder /etc/swiftlm/builder_dir/region-region1/account.builder rebalance 999", "NOTE: No partitions could be reassigned.", "Either none need to be or none can be due to min_part_hours [16]."
The text No partitions could be reassigned indicates that no further rebalances are necessary. If this is true for all the rings, you have completed the final phase.You must have allowed enough time to elapse since the last rebalance. As mentioned in the above example, min_part_hours [16] means that you must wait at least 16 hours since the last rebalance. If not, you should wait until enough time has elapsed and repeat this phase.
Run the reconfigure.cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts swift-reconfigure.yml
Wait until replication has finished or min-part-time has elapsed (which ever is longer). For more information see
Repeat the above steps until the ring is rebalanced.

section.title: System change that change existing rings
section.p: There are many system changes ranging from adding servers to replacing drives that might require some ring rebuild and rebalance actions.

ul.li: If not already done, set the weight change attribute as described in Swift preparing ring changes.

Add servers in phases
This reduces the impact of the changes on your system.
If your rings use Swift zones, ensure you remove the same number of servers to each zone at each phase.
To add a server, follow the procedure described in Adding a New Node/Server.
Follow the instructions mentioned in to incrementally change the weights and perform the final rebalance.

stentry.p:
In HP Helion OpenStack 2.0, when you remove servers from the input model, the disk drives are removed from the ring â€“ the weight is not gradually reduced using the weight-step attribute.
Remove servers in phases
This reduces the impact of the changes on your system.
If your rings use Swift zones, ensure you remove the same number of servers to each zone at each phase.

ul.li: To remove a server, follow the procedure described in Removing a Swift Node.
Follow the instructions mentioned in to perform the final rebalance.

strow.stentry:
When a drive fails, replace it as soon as possible. Do not attempt to remove it from the ring â€“ this creates to operator overhead. Swift will continue to store the correct number of replicas by "handing off" objects to other drives instead of the failed drive.If the disk drives are of the same size as the original when the drive is replaced, no ring changes are required. You can confirm this by running the _swift-make-delta-rebalance.yml playbook. It should report that no weight changes are needed.
For a single drive replacement, even if the drive is significantly larger than the original drives then you do not need to rebalance the ring (however, the extra space on the drive will not be used).

stentry.p: If the drives are different size (for example, you are upgrading your system), you can proceed as follows:

ul.li: If not already done, set the weight-step attribute

Replace drives in phases
Avoid replacing too many drives at once.
If your rings use swift zones, upgrade a number of drives in the same zone at the same time â€“ not drives in several zones.
It is also safer to upgrade one server instead of drives in several servers at the same time.
Remember that the final size of all Swift zones must be the same, so you may need to replace a small number of drives in one zone, then a small number in second zone, then return to the first zone and replace more drives, etc.
